vocabulary.example: Porous rock allows water to seep through easily.
The river deposited silt along its banks, enriching the soil.
Debris can clog irrigation channels and prevent water flow.
The dike protected the farmland from seasonal flooding.
The inundation of the valley forced thousands to evacuate.
Heavy rains inundated the low-lying areas near the river.
The empire faced a serious predicament when the river changed course.
The emperor convened his advisors to discuss the flooding crisis.
Local leaders pledged to contribute resources for flood control.
Poor infrastructure hindered efforts to manage the water system.
The fertile land produced abundant crops for the empire.
Scribes reproduced important documents for distribution.
The inscription on the monument commemorated the flood control project.
Workers erected a massive stone monument to honor the emperor.
The engineer received an award for his meritorious service.
The plan had merit but required significant resources.
The neutralization of flood threats required coordinated efforts.
The monsoon season brought heavy rains and flooding.
Agriculture was the foundation of the empire's economy.
Seasonal flooding was inevitable in the river valley.
The emperor imposed new taxes to fund irrigation projects.
Several principalities united under the empire's rule.
The principal concern was preventing catastrophic flooding.
Imperial decrees mandated cooperation on water management.
The empire controlled vast territories along the river.
Farmers customarily planted crops after the flood season.
It was customary to offer prayers before major construction projects.
Grazing lands were located on higher ground away from floods.
The military launched an offensive to secure water resources.
The empire promoted cultural homogeneity across its territories.
Scientists invoke plate tectonics to explain mountain formation.
Terrestrial mountains differ significantly from underwater formations.
The expedition explored uncharted territory in the mountain range.
The contraction of Earth's crust creates compressional forces.
The incandescent lava flowed down the mountainside.
Tectonic forces deform rock layers over millions of years.
Alfred Wegener popularized the theory of continental drift.
The theory must accommodate new evidence from ocean floor studies.
Earth's crust is divided into several tectonic plates.
The ocean basin contains the deepest parts of the seafloor.
The age distribution of ocean rocks was perplexing to early geologists.
The discovery perplexed scientists who expected older rocks.
The puzzle of seafloor spreading was solved in the 1960s.
Magnetic stripes interleave across the ocean floor.
The interleaving pattern of rock types indicates periodic volcanic activity.
Sediment accumulates on the ocean floor over time.
Rivers deposit sediment in deltas where they meet the ocean.
Stratigraphic analysis reveals the history of rock formation.
Different strata contain fossils from different time periods.
The striking symmetry of magnetic patterns confirmed seafloor spreading.
The absence of old oceanic crust was a major conundrum.
Scientists attribute mountain building to plate collisions.
Feldspar is a common mineral in continental crust.
Olivine is abundant in the Earth's mantle and oceanic crust.
Pyroxene minerals are found in basaltic rocks.
Volcanic craters dot the landscape of the island chain.
The seafloor subsides as it moves away from the mid-ocean ridge.
Paleontology provides evidence for the age of rock formations.
Wind and water erode mountains over geological time.
